content.confidence: 3: You are fairly confident in your assessment. It is possible that you did not understand some parts of the submission or that you are unfamiliar with some pieces of related work. Math/other details were not carefully checked.
content.summary_of_the_paper: Deep learning-based forecasting techniques for multi-variate time series forecasting have largely replaced more traditional techniques in recent years. However, there is an overall lack of consensus on the effectiveness of such methods overall, and the value of using more complex transformer-based methods has become increasingly incremental. In this work, the authors combine standard practices of time series decomposition into trend and seasonality components with channel-wise sequence dependencies in order to obtain multi-step-ahead forecasts in a more principled and efficient manner. The authors also consider an extension to this method that applies contrastive learning to the seasonal components. The authors verify the effectiveness of these models by applying them to a selection of time series forecasting and anomaly detection problems.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
- The proposed models combine classical decomposition-based approaches for time series forecasting with more recent deep learning techniques. The experiment results indicate that they perform consistently well across a variety of datasets, often outperforming competing methods. 
- I also appreciate that the experimental evaluation is fairly extensive, and considers a variety of both time series forecasting datasets, as well as anomaly detection benchmarks.

-------

- Overall, I found that the paper lacks focus, and I’m not sure why anomaly detection is featured so prominently in the title and introduction, when there doesn’t seem to be much contribution in that area? I see anomaly detection in this case as being a downstream task from forecasting, and it stands to reason that improved forecasts should in turn result in more reliable anomaly detection. There does not seem to be any other contribution to anomaly detection beyond this however, and the focus of the paper remains on time series forecasting.
- The paper contains a fair amount of typos and would have definitely benefited from more thorough proofreading before submission. I advise the authors to look out for these when preparing a future revision.
- It seems like the majority of the paper’s contributions are quite empirically-driven, with claims such as “We also tried to utilise a trend component … but the performance is not improved when compared with the mean value.” While I appreciate this practical tip, the insight comes across as superficial overall, and it feels as though there was less underlying theoretical motivation for the architecture of the model.
- The inclusion of the contrastive learning element also only has marginal value, and may even distract from the focus of the decomposition-based dual projection model that is the primary contribution.
content.clarity,_quality,_novelty_and_reproducib: The proposed architectures of DBDP and DBDPC are novel, but they also borrow very heavily from existing papers on transformer-based models and contrastive learning for forecasting. I think the paper’s focus on anomaly detection is currently misleading as, unless I’ve misunderstood, this is here purely a downstream task that benefits from a method yielding better forecasts. I think the paper would benefit from major rewriting overall - the Related Work section currently takes up a lot of space in the main paper, which could instead be used to describe DBDP in more detail. It would also be helpful to include more illustrative figures/synthetic examples that showcase how the model compares against existing methods.
content.summary_of_the_review: Although there are some interesting concepts presented in this submission, it ultimately comes across as incomplete, and I believe it would require major revisions in order to be fit for acceptance.
content.correctness: 3: Some of the paper’s claims have minor issues. A few statements are not well-supported, or require small changes to be made correct.
content.technical_novelty_and_significance: 2: The contributions are only marginally significant or novel.
content.empirical_novelty_and_significance: 2: The contributions are only marginally significant or novel.

content.confidence: 2: You are willing to defend your assessment, but it is quite likely that you did not understand the central parts of the submission or that you are unfamiliar with some pieces of related work. Math/other details were not carefully checked.
content.summary_of_the_paper: This manuscript proposed a new model with direct projections for long-sequence time series forecasting and anomaly detection. The proposed DBDP model is composed of an anchored global profile and a varied number of decomposed seasonal local, and additionally introduces a contrastive learning module for improving forecasting. Extensive comparison against current time series forecasting methods demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
Pros:
1. The architecture of the proposed method is simple and flexible.
2. Extensive experiments regarding time series forecasting and anomaly detection have been conducted.

Cons:
1. The contribution is incremental since it looks like a combination of several existing techniques.
2. The description of the proposed method is unclear. For example, how to perform time series decomposition and dual projection? how to perform prediction under current modeling framework? The authors are suggested to elaborate on the implementations of the proposed model.
3. Appendix A mentioned the ablation study of the anchor. What is the anchor in the proposed method? The reviewer did not find the description of “anchor” in the main text.
4. Regarding the reported experimental results, it is hard to say that there exists significant difference between for example DLinear and the proposed method. Statistical tests are suggested to perform for validating the superiority of the proposed method.
5. There are some typos in the manuscript. Please carefully check through the whole manuscript.
content.clarity,_quality,_novelty_and_reproducib: The unclear description regarding the proposed method hinders the understanding and evaluation of this manuscript.
content.summary_of_the_review: Though with extensive experiments for model evaluation, the proposed method is suffered from the incremental contribution and the unclear description.
content.correctness: 3: Some of the paper’s claims have minor issues. A few statements are not well-supported, or require small changes to be made correct.
content.technical_novelty_and_significance: 2: The contributions are only marginally significant or novel.
content.empirical_novelty_and_significance: 2: The contributions are only marginally significant or novel.

content.confidence: 4: You are confident in your assessment, but not absolutely certain. It is unlikely, but not impossible, that you did not understand some parts of the submission or that you are unfamiliar with some pieces of related work.
content.summary_of_the_paper:
This paper proposed a time series decomposition-based method to model the temporal and variable dependence for forecasting and anomaly detection.
The proposed method includes a contrastive learning module.
The experimental evaluation compares the proposed method with some Transformer based methods.
content.strength_and_weaknesses:
Modeling the temporal-wise and variable-wise correlations (or temporal-spatial relations) in multivariate time analyses is an extensively studied subject, e.g., [1, 2, 3]. The techniques used in the proposed method are quite standard. It seems no new insights are unlocked in this paper. Meanwhile, the presentation of this paper needs substantial improvement. 

[a] there is no clear problem definition. The presentation of the proposed method is mostly descriptive and lacks rigorous mathematical expression/definition. 

[b] Too many ambiguous claims/terminologies, e.g., in Sec 1,  "all the key performance contributing blocks, such as the channel projection that serves as the value embedding, and the sequence projection that generates the multi-step outputs".    

  "the channel projection" is introduced in the main contribution in Sec. 1. Then, in Sec. 3.1, similar terms "channel-wise sequence projection" and "the step-wise channel projection" are shown. Neither of them has a clear definition or mathematical expression.

[c] the motivation for equipping the proposed method with contrastive learning is insufficiently provided, .e.g, "a contrastive learning module attached to DBDP, inspired by the self-supervised learning." this leads to confusion. 

[d] what is the math definition of  "dual projections" in the context of this paper?

[e] in the experiment section,  Table 3 only reports the results on two datasets. It is not convincing enough to justify the effectiveness of contrastive learning, given the 9 datasets reported in Table 2.

[f] In Table 2, some results of DLinear are a bit worse than the results in the original paper [4], which would lead to misleading conclusions. 

[1] Guo, Tian, Tao Lin, and Nino Antulov-Fantulin. "Exploring interpretable LSTM neural networks over multi-variable data." International conference on machine learning. PMLR, 2019.

[2] Pal, Soumyasundar, et al. "RNN with particle flow for probabilistic spatio-temporal forecasting." International Conference on Machine Learning. PMLR, 2021.

[3] Yang, Ling, and Shenda Hong. "Unsupervised time-series representation learning with iterative bilinear temporal-spectral fusion." International Conference on Machine Learning. PMLR, 2022.

[4] Zeng, Ailing, et al. "Are Transformers Effective for Time Series Forecasting?." arXiv preprint arXiv:2205.13504 (2022).
content.clarity,_quality,_novelty_and_reproducib:
This paper is focused on a well-studied problem.
The proposed method has no new ideas, nor reveals new insights into the techniques used in this paper.
Some design choices are not justified theoretically and experimentally.
The presentation of this paper needs substantial improvement.
content.summary_of_the_review:
Modeling the temporal-wise and variable-wise correlations (or temporal-spatial relations) in multivariate time analyses is an extensively studied subject. The techniques used in the proposed method are quite standard and no new insights are unlocked. The presentation of this paper needs substantial improvement. The experiment evaluation contains some inaccurate results of a baseline, compared with the results in the original papers of the baseline.  
Meanwhile, it is not convincing enough to justify the effectiveness of contrastive learning by showing the results on 2 datasets, given the 9 datasets are used in total.
content.correctness: 2: Several of the paper’s claims are incorrect or not well-supported.
content.technical_novelty_and_significance: 2: The contributions are only marginally significant or novel.
content.empirical_novelty_and_significance: 1: The contributions are neither significant nor novel.
